    "let @xmath0 and let @xmath1 be the polyhedral cone in @xmath2 spanned by @xmath3 .",
    "the configuration @xmath3 is _ normal _ if every lattice point in @xmath1 is a non - negative integer combination of @xmath3 .",
    "we say that @xmath3 is _ supernormal _ if , for every subset @xmath4 of @xmath3 , every lattice point in @xmath5 is a non - negative integer combination of @xmath6 .",
    "in section 2 we discuss supernormal configurations in low dimensions .",
    "in particular , we exhibit a finitely generated submonoid of @xmath7 which can not be generated by a finite supernormal subset .",
    "this implies that in general the process of normalization ( * ? ? ?",
    "* algorithm 13.2 ) can not be extended to produce a finite supernormal generating set .",
    "in section 3 we characterize supernormal vector configurations in terms of polyhedral geometry ( triangulations ) and in terms of integer programming ( total dual integrality ) . this will generalize the familiar characterizations of unimodular configurations @xcite . recall that a configuration @xmath3 in @xmath8 is _ unimodular _",
    "if , for every subset @xmath4 of @xmath3 , every lattice point in @xmath9 is a non - negative integer combination of @xmath4 .    the algebraic theory of integer programming is closely related to grbner bases of binomial ideals @xcite .",
    "we encode our configuration @xmath3 as the ideal @xmath10 in the polynomial ring @xmath11 $ ] generated by @xmath12 in the language of @xcite or @xcite , the ideal @xmath10 is the _ lattice ideal _ for the lattice spanned by the rows of the @xmath13-matrix @xmath14 .",

    "two vectors @xmath21 lie in the same cell of the _ grbner fan of @xmath10 _ if @xmath22 , and they lie in the same cell of the _ chamber complex of @xmath3 _ if , for every subset @xmath23 of @xmath3 , @xmath24 if and only if @xmath25 . in section 4",
    "we prove :    [ gb = chamber ] if the configuration @xmath3 is supernormal then the chamber complex of @xmath3 coincides with the grbner fan of @xmath10 .",
    "we note that the converse statement does not hold , even for @xmath26 . for the special case",
    "when @xmath3 is unimodular , this theorem follows from ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition 8.15 ) via gale duality .",
    "our proof will be self - contained .",
    "a longstanding conjecture @xcite states that the number of facets of any chamber in the grbner fan of @xmath10 is bounded by a function of @xmath27 alone , independent of the coordinates of the @xmath28 . in section 5",
    "we examine this question for the supernormal configuration @xmath29 associated with a convex lattice polygon @xmath30 in the plane .",
    "the chamber complex of @xmath3 is gotten by drawing the line segments connecting any two lattice points in @xmath30 as in figure [ 2x3grid ] .",
    "it is an open question whether polygons with arbitrarily many edges can appear in such a picture .",
    "see proposition [ world - record ] for the current status of the problem .",
    "the chambers of a vector configuration @xmath3 are in bijection with the _ regular triangulations _ of a gale dual configuration @xmath31 .",
    "this was extended in @xcite to a bijection between all triangulations of @xmath31 and _ virtual chambers _ of @xmath3 .",
    "we reexamine these concepts in section 6 , and we introduce the following algebraic analogue : a monomial ideal @xmath32 in @xmath11 $ ] is a _ virtual initial ideal _ of @xmath10 if @xmath32 has the same hilbert function as @xmath10 with respect to the finest grading which makes @xmath10 homogeneous . in @xcite",
    "such @xmath32 were called",
    "_ @xmath31-graded monomial ideals_. there is a map from virtual initial ideals to virtual chambers ( defined by ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 10.10 ) ) but this map is in general neither injective nor surjective .",
    "our main result is the following extension of theorem [ gb = chamber ] .",
    "[ unimodular2 ] if the configuration @xmath3 is supernormal then the map from virtual initial ideals of @xmath10 to virtual chambers of @xmath3 is a bijection .",
    "in this section we study examples of supernormal configurations in low dimensions . recall that a configuration @xmath3 of vectors in @xmath8 is _ normal _ if it generates the monoid @xmath33 .",

    "clearly , if @xmath3 is a hilbert basis then @xmath3 is normal .",

    "but @xmath3 is supernormal if and only if either @xmath41 , or @xmath42 , or @xmath46 .",
    "thus @xmath47 is normal but not supernormal .",

    "the ideal @xmath49 has two initial ideals , but for @xmath50 we get @xmath51 which has only one initial ideal .",
    "this shows that the converse to theorem [ gb = chamber ] does not hold .",
    "the configuration @xmath3 is pointed if and only if either @xmath52 or @xmath53 .",
    "note that in this case @xmath3 is normal if and only if either @xmath54 or @xmath55 .",
    "we conclude that a one dimensional pointed configuration is normal if and only if it is supernormal .",

    "therefore @xmath3 is supernormal .",
    "[ twohilb ] every two - dimensional hilbert basis is supernormal .    in the language of algebraic geometry , this says that @xmath72 is supernormal if and only if the toric surface @xmath73 is smooth , where @xmath74 is the fan whose rays are the vectors in @xmath3 . in higher dimensions , supernormality means that all toric varieties that share a fixed cox homogeneous coordinate ring are smooth .",
    "this follows from proposition [ uni - triang ] below .",

    "the configuration @xmath3 is not supernormal . to see this",

    "if we add the vector @xmath84 to @xmath3 then the resulting configuration of seven vectors is supernormal .",
    "it is well - known that the monoid of lattice points in any rational polyhedral cone has a finite hilbert basis . in the previous example , the hilbert basis can be enlarged to a finite supernormal generating set .",
    "this raises the question of whether every rational submonoid of @xmath8 is generated by a finite supernormal subset .",
    "this is not the case .",
    "the monoid of lattice points in the three - dimensional cone spanned by @xmath85 and @xmath86 is not generated by a finite supernormal subset .",
    "consider the following sequence of vectors in this monoid : @xmath87 where @xmath88 .",
    "explicitly , @xmath89 at each stage in this iteration , the three vectors @xmath90 generate an index two sublattice of @xmath91 , and @xmath92 is the unique vector which completes the hilbert basis for their triangular cone .",
    "suppose there is a finite supernormal generating set @xmath3 for the ambient monoid and consider the smallest index @xmath36 such that @xmath92 is not in @xmath3 .",
    "then the subset @xmath93 violates the defining property of @xmath3 being supernormal .",
    "while this result shows that not every configuration can be embedded into a supernormal one , there do exist interesting specific supernormal configurations in higher dimensions , beyond the familiar class of unimodular configurations .",
    "here is an example for @xmath75 :    the configuration @xmath94 of all @xmath95 vectors whose coordinates have absolute value at most one is supernormal .    a configuration obtained from all lattice points in a lattice polytope as in ( [ bintheplane ] )",
    "is called _",
    "convex_. the three dimensional convex configurations ( [ bintheplane ] ) arising from polygons play a special role and are discussed in detail in section [ polygon ] . in proposition [ polygonsupernormal ]",
    "we show that they are supernormal .",
    ".2 cm    * dimension four and beyond : * most convex configurations in higher dimensions are not supernormal , however .",
    "consider the cone over the three - dimensional cube given by the columns of @xmath96 this configuration of eight vectors in @xmath97 is convex but not supernormal .",
    "what is missing is the vector @xmath98 which represents the centroid of the cube .",
    "the configuration together with @xmath99 is supernormal",
    ".    it would be interesting to identify infinite families of configurations in higher dimensions which are supernormal but not unimodular .",
    "such families might arise from graph theory or combinatorial optimization .",
    "in this section we present two characterizations of supernormal configurations @xmath3 .",
    "the first is in terms of triangulations , and the second involves the concept of total dual integrality from integer programming .",
    "a _ subdivision _ of a vector configuration @xmath100 is a polyhedral fan @xmath74 in @xmath2 whose support is @xmath101 and each of whose rays is spanned by a vector @xmath28 @xcite .",
    "it is customary to identify @xmath74 with the collection of subsets @xmath102 of @xmath3 which lie in the maximal cones of @xmath74 .",
    "a subdivision @xmath74 is _ regular _ if there exists a vector @xmath103 such that @xmath104 is a face of @xmath74 if and only if @xmath105 and @xmath106 otherwise .",
    "a subdivision @xmath74 of @xmath3 is a _ triangulation _ if each maximal cell @xmath102 has precisely @xmath27 elements .",
    "a triangulation @xmath74 of @xmath3 is _ unimodular _ if every maximal cell @xmath102 is a lattice basis for @xmath8 .",
    "the triangulation @xmath74 _ uses all vectors _ if each element @xmath28 of @xmath3 spans a ray of the fan @xmath74 .",
    "a configuration @xmath3 is unimodular if and only if every triangulation of @xmath3 is unimodular .",
    "here it suffices to consider regular triangulations .",
    "we prove an analogous characterization for supernormal configurations .",
    "[ uni - triang ] for a configuration @xmath3 , the following are equivalent :    1 .",
    "@xmath3 is supernormal .",
    "every triangulation of @xmath3 that uses all vectors is unimodular .",
    "every regular triangulation of @xmath3 that uses all vectors is unimodular .    -.3",
    "cm    we first prove @xmath107 .",
    "let @xmath3 be supernormal , @xmath74 a triangulation that uses all vectors , and @xmath108 a maximal cell of @xmath74 .",
    "if @xmath102 is not a lattice basis of @xmath8 then @xmath102 does not generate the monoid @xmath109 .",
    "supernormality implies that @xmath110 contains at least one other vector @xmath111 , but then this vector @xmath67 can not be used in the triangulation @xmath74 .",
    "this contradicts our hypothesis .",
    "the implication @xmath112 is trivial .",
    "it remains to show @xmath113 .",
    "suppose ( 3 ) holds .",
    "let @xmath4 be any subset of @xmath3 .",
    "we construct a regular subdivision of @xmath3 which has @xmath114 as one of its faces , and which uses all vectors in @xmath115 as rays .",
    "this subdivision can be refined to a regular triangulation @xmath74 of @xmath3 that uses all vectors . by hypothesis ,",
    "@xmath74 is unimodular , and its restriction to @xmath102 is a unimodular triangulation of @xmath102 .",
    "this implies that @xmath102 generates the monoid @xmath116 .",
    "we conclude that @xmath3 is supernormal .",
    "regular subdivisions are polar to the polyhedra with facet normals in @xmath117 .",
    "more precisely , for @xmath103 we define the polyhedron @xmath118 let @xmath119 denote the normal fan of the convex polyhedron @xmath120 .",
    "[ regular = fan ] the normal fan @xmath119 is a regular subdivision of @xmath3 .",
    "every regular subdivision of @xmath3 is the normal fan of @xmath120 for some @xmath103 .",
    "these statements follow from the fact that @xmath119 is the regular subdivision induced by the vector @xmath121 .",
    "we recall the following definition from integer programming . a good reference for these topics",
    "is chapter 22 of schrijver s book @xcite .",
    "a system of rational inequalities @xmath122 is called _ totally dual integral _ ( tdi )",
    "if for each @xmath123 such that the linear program @xmath124 has a finite optimal solution , the dual linear program @xmath125 has an integral solution .",
    "the property of being tdi is a property of the given representation of a polyhedron in terms of inequalities , and not of the polyhedron itself . in what follows ,",
    "whenever we say `` the polyhedron @xmath120 is tdi '' , what we mean is that the inequality system @xmath126 is tdi .",
    "the following characterization of unimodular configurations is easily derived from the basic properties of tdi systems @xcite .",
    "the vector configuration @xmath127 is unimodular if and only if the polyhedron @xmath120 is tdi for every @xmath103 .",
    "we will prove an analogous result for supernormal configurations by considering only those polyhedra @xmath120 where @xmath121 ranges over a certain subset of @xmath128 .",
    "first we give a name to these special polyhedra .",
    "the system of inequalities defining @xmath120 is _ tight _ if @xmath129 is strictly contained in @xmath130 for every unit vector @xmath131 .",
    "tightness is a property not of the polyhedron @xmath120 but of the inequality system @xmath132 .",
    "however , as with tdi , we shall abuse language by simply saying `` @xmath133 is tight '' . with this convention ,",
    "@xmath120 is tight if and only if , for each @xmath134 , there exists a lattice point @xmath135 with @xmath136 .",
    "[ tight = tdi ] the vector configuration @xmath127 is supernormal if and only if every tight polyhedron @xmath120 is tdi .    we first prove the if direction using condition ( 3 ) in proposition [ uni - triang ] .",
    "let @xmath74 be a regular triangulation of @xmath3 which uses all vectors .",
    "we wish to show that @xmath74 is a unimodular triangulation . by lemma [ regular = fan ]",
    "there is a simple polyhedron @xmath120 whose normal fan equals @xmath74 .",
    "in particular , every vector @xmath28 defines a facet of @xmath120 .",
    "since @xmath120 is a rational polyhedron , there is some @xmath137 such that @xmath138 is integral .",
    "the polyhedron @xmath139 has normal fan @xmath74 , and is tight , and so is tdi by assumption .",
    "theorem 22.5 in @xcite implies that every set @xmath102 of @xmath27 vectors in @xmath3 that define a vertex of @xmath139 is a basis of @xmath8 .",
    "these cones @xmath102 are the maximal cells of @xmath74 .",
    "hence @xmath74 is unimodular and we conclude that @xmath3 is supernormal .    for the only - if direction , suppose that @xmath3 is supernormal and let @xmath140 be such that @xmath120 is tight .",
    "consider any face @xmath141 of @xmath120 , and let @xmath102 be the set of all vectors @xmath142 such @xmath143 holds for all @xmath144 . in view of (",
    "* theorem 22.5 ) , it suffices to prove that @xmath102 is a hilbert basis .",
    "suppose this is not true .",

    "we know that there is some @xmath150 for which @xmath151 .",
    "the first of these two statements implies @xmath152 .",
    "the second implies @xmath153 .",
    "but these two statements contradict each other , and so we conclude that @xmath67 does not exist , and thus @xmath102 is a hilbert basis .",
    "it follows that @xmath120 is tdi .",
    "the goal of this section is to prove theorem [ gb = chamber ] which states that the chamber complex equals the grbner fan if @xmath3 is supernormal .",
    "we start out by characterizing these two fans by means of the polyhedra @xmath120 . in the next two lemmas",
    ", @xmath3 is an arbitrary configuration in @xmath8 .",
    "[ ch - complex ] the chamber complex of @xmath154 is the common refinement of the normal fans @xmath155 as @xmath121 runs over @xmath156 .    according to the definition given in the introduction ,",
    "two vectors lie in the same cell of the chamber complex if and only if they lie in exactly the same cones spanned by linearly independent @xmath27-subsets of @xmath3 .",
    "this holds if and only if , for every regular subdivision @xmath74 of @xmath3 , they lie in the same cell of @xmath74 .",
    "lemma [ regular = fan ] completes the proof .",
    "lemma [ ch - complex ] coincides with the first statement in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition 3.3.5 ) .",
    "the term _ secondary fan _ is often used for the chamber complex . for @xmath103",
    "consider the lattice polyhedron @xmath157 this is the convex hull of all lattice points in the polyhedron @xmath158 .",
    "[ gbfan ] the grbner fan of the binomial ideal @xmath159 $ ] is the common refinement of the normal fans @xmath160 as @xmath121 runs over @xmath156 .    this is the second statement of ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition 3.3.5 ) .",

    "hence @xmath165 .",
    "this proves the following well - known result :    for any configuration @xmath154 , the grbner fan of the ideal @xmath10 refines the chamber complex of @xmath3 .",
    "this says that the cones in the chamber complex of @xmath3 can split into smaller cones as one passes to the grbner fan of @xmath10 .",
    "it is known that no splitting happens when @xmath3 is a unimodular configuration ; see for example ( * ? ? ?",
    "* proposition 8.15 ( a ) ) .",
    "theorem [ gb = chamber ] says that no splitting happens even when @xmath3 is only supernormal . to prove this",

    "in this section we study convex vector configurations of the following form : @xmath183 we first show that they are all supernormal .",
    "[ polygonsupernormal ] every convex configuration in @xmath91 is supernormal .    let @xmath3 be a convex configuration in @xmath91 and consider any triangulation @xmath74 of @xmath3 that uses all vectors",
    ". now a lattice triangle in the plane which contains no other lattice point has area one half ( by pick s theorem , for example ) .",
    "this implies that the triangulation @xmath74 is unimodular , and so proposition [ uni - triang ] implies that @xmath3 is supernormal .",
    "the _ chamber complex _ of the polygon @xmath30 is the common refinement of all lattice triangulations of @xmath30 .",
    "hence the chamber complex of the vector configuration @xmath3 is simply the cone over the chamber complex of @xmath30 .",
    "we draw the chamber complex of @xmath30 by connecting any pair of lattice points in @xmath30 by a straight line segment .    for example",
    ", if @xmath30 is the quadrangle with vertices @xmath184 , and @xmath185 , then @xmath3 is the set of column vectors of the @xmath186-matrix : @xmath187 the chamber complex of @xmath30 is the subdivision of @xmath30 into @xmath188 triangles , five quadrilaterals , and one pentagon , which is depicted in figure [ fiveeg ] .",
    "we write @xmath189 for the maximum number of edges of any region in the chamber complex of a lattice polygon @xmath30 .",
    "for instance , in figure [ fiveeg ] we have @xmath190 .",
    "the main point of this section is the open question of whether there exists a global upper bound for the numbers @xmath189 .",
    "[ pp ] ( the polygon problem ) does there exists a constant @xmath191 such that every convex lattice polygon @xmath30 satisfies @xmath192  ?",
    "we circulated this problem in october 2000 , and in the meantime considerable progress has been made by several people .",
    "however , the problem remains open for now . with @xmath193 .",
    "] later in this section we will summarize what is known at the present time ( april 2001 ) .",
    "the polygon problem is important to us because it is a special case of a conjecture in the algebraic theory of integer programming .",
    "sturmfels and thomas ( * ? ? ?",
    "* conjecture 6.1 ) asked whether there exists a finite bound @xmath194 on the number of facets of any cone in the grbner fan of an ideal @xmath10 having codimension @xmath27 .",
    "such a bound would have implications for the sensitivity analysis of integer programming in fixed dimension @xmath27 .",
    "it is obvious that @xmath195 , and it was conjectured in ( * ? ? ? * conjecture 6.2 ) that @xmath196 . the latter conjecture was much too optimistic .",
    "it is now easily seen to be false : figure [ fiveeg ] together with the following proposition implies @xmath197 :    every lattice polygon @xmath30 satisfies @xmath198 .",
    "the chamber complex of a supernormal configuration @xmath3 is the grbner fan of the associated binomial ideal @xmath10 .",
    "hence @xmath194 is greater or equal to the maximum number of facets of any cone in the chamber complex of a supernormal configuration in @xmath8 . for @xmath199 we can take the chamber complex of a polygon @xmath30 to get a lower bound for @xmath200",
    "the first counterexamples to ( * ? ? ?",
    "* conjecture 6.2 ) were given by hoten and maclagan @xcite who showed that @xmath201 .",
    "however , the question of whether @xmath200 is finite remains open . a negative answer to the polygon problem would show that @xmath194 is infinite for @xmath202 .    to illustrate our algebraic interpretation of planar chamber complexes , we translate the marked pentagonal chamber in figure [ fiveeg ] into a specific reduced grbner basis of binomials .",
    "our ideal is generated by the three binomials corresponding to the rows of the matrix in ( [ threebyeight ] ) : @xmath203 we next fix a term order which refines any non - negative real weight vector @xmath204 with the property that @xmath205 lies in the marked pentagonal chamber of @xmath206 .",
    "for instance , we can take @xmath207 .",
    "the reduced grbner basis of @xmath10 with respect to this term order equals : @xmath208 @xmath209 @xmath210 the five `` flippable '' grbner basis elements are underlined .",
    "they correspond to the five edges of the pentagonal chamber in figure [ fiveeg ] .",
    ".3 cm    we shall now present what is known on the polygon problem .",
    "the following result is an outgrowth of the combined efforts of miguel azaola , jess de loera , jrg rambau , francisco santos , marc pfetsch and gnter ziegler . in november 2000 ,",
    "the first four of these obtained the lower bound of @xmath211 .",
    "it is attained by the @xmath212 lattice rectangle . in april 2001 ,",
    "the last two succeeded in improving the previous world record from @xmath211 to @xmath213 .",
    "this is the currently best known bound .",
    "[ world - record ] if @xmath30 is the @xmath214 lattice rectangle then @xmath215 , and hence @xmath216 .",
    "pfetsch and ziegler have made extensive calculations of the numbers @xmath189 for various lattice rectangles @xmath30 .",
    "their computational results are posted at the website    http://www.math.tu-berlin.de/~pfetsch/chambers/    the data posted at this website seem to suggest that the answer to the question in problem [ pp ] is more likely to be negative .",
    "the example referred to in the proposition above consists of all lattice points @xmath217 where @xmath218 and @xmath219 .",
    "pfetsch and ziegler identified two chambers which are @xmath213-gons in the unit square with vertices @xmath220 .",
    "note that one of the edges of this square lies on the boundary of the @xmath214 lattice rectangle .",
    "it seems that this is not a coincidence : ernest croot has shown that any chamber with many edges must be located close to the boundary of @xmath30 .",
    "the paper with croot s precise results is forthcoming .",
    "in section [ chambers ] we established the bijection between chambers of a supernormal configuration @xmath3 and initial monomial ideals of @xmath10 . in this section",
    "we will extend it to a bijection between _ virtual _ chambers of @xmath3 and _ virtual _ initial ideals of @xmath10 , proving theorem [ unimodular2 ] .",
    "first we define these objects and explain how the bijection works .    throughout this section",
    "we assume that @xmath221 generates the lattice @xmath222 .",
    "this holds if @xmath3 is supernormal by proposition [ uni - triang ] . under this hypothesis",
    "we can find a configuration @xmath223 such that the integer kernel of the @xmath224 matrix @xmath225 is spanned by the rows of the matrix @xmath14 .",
    "we will also use the notation @xmath31 for the first matrix and @xmath3 for the second one .",
    "the relationship between @xmath31 and @xmath3 is called _ gale duality _",
    "* chapter 6 ) .",
    "it is well - known ( @xcite , @xcite ) that the poset of regular subdivisions of @xmath31 ( ordered by refinement ) is antiisomorphic to the face poset of the chamber complex of @xmath3 .",
    "the minimal elements of the poset of regular subdivisions of @xmath31 are the regular triangulations of @xmath31 and they correspond to the full - dimensional chambers of @xmath3 .",
    "this correspondence can be described explicitly .",
    "let @xmath226 be the maximal cells of a regular triangulation of @xmath31 where @xmath227 .",
    "this defines the chamber @xmath228 where @xmath229 .",
    "the bijection between the regular triangulations of @xmath31 and the maximal chambers of @xmath3 was extended in @xcite to _ all _ triangulations of @xmath31 .",
    "the configuration in figure [ 2x3grid ] of the introduction is given by the columns of the matrix @xmath231 this configuration @xmath3 has @xmath232 virtual chambers .",
    "@xmath233 of these are chambers and hence visible in figure [ 2x3grid ] .",
    "the two additional virtual chambers are @xmath234 @xmath235 we invite the reader to `` locate '' these virtual chambers in figure [ 2x3grid ] , and to draw the two non - regular triangulations of @xmath31 .",
    "we define an @xmath236-dimensional grading of the polynomial ring @xmath237 $ ] by setting the degree of @xmath238 to be @xmath239 for @xmath240 .",
    "thus @xmath241 is graded by the monoid @xmath242 which is spanned by the gale dual configuration @xmath31 .",
    "the ideal @xmath10 is homogeneous in this grading since @xmath243 the hilbert function of the quotient ring @xmath244 is given by @xmath245 a homogeneous ideal in @xmath241 with the same hilbert function as @xmath10 was called an @xmath31-graded ideal in @xcite .",
    "monomial @xmath31-graded ideals include , but are not limited to , initial ideals of @xmath16 .",
    "[ defofvirtual ] a monomial ideal @xmath32 in @xmath241 is a _ virtual initial ideal _ of @xmath10 if the hilbert function of @xmath246 is equal to the hilbert function ( [ hilf ] ) .",
    "this means that for every degree @xmath247 there is exactly one monomial @xmath174 of degree @xmath248 with the property that @xmath249 .    to illustrate this definition and theorem [ unimodular2 ] we compute a virtual initial ideal of @xmath10 for ( [ threebysix ] ) .",
    "first consider @xmath250 .",
    "then @xmath251 this @xmath31-graded ideal corresponds to the centroid in figure [ 2x3grid ] . by replacing each of the three binomials by one of its terms , we get eight virtual initial ideals of @xmath10 , one for each virtual chamber adjacent to the centroid in figure [ 2x3grid ] .",
    "for instance , taking the first term in each of the three binomial generators of @xmath252 gives the virtual initial ideal @xmath253 we pass to the radical of this ideal by erasing all exponents , and deleting the embedded component at the end .",
    "the eight remaining index sets are precisely the cells in the first virtual chamber listed for example ( [ threebysix ] ) .",
    "this process of using primary decomposition to read off the virtual chamber from a given virtual initial ideal works in general :      this remark follows essentially from ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 10.10 ) .",
    "we shall give an alternative description of the map ( [ mappp ] ) after lemma [ section ] below .",
    "that description will be self - contained , with no reference to @xcite needed , and better suited for the purpose of proving theorem [ unimodular2 ] .    for arbitrary configurations @xmath3 , the map ( [ mappp ] )",
    "is neither injective nor surjective .",
    "two virtual initial ideals can give rise to the same virtual chamber and there might be virtual chambers which do not correspond to virtual initial ideals ( * ? ? ?",
    "* theorem 10.13 ) .",
    "what we are claiming in theorem [ unimodular2 ] is that for supernormal configurations @xmath3 the map ( [ mappp ] ) is both injective and surjective . in the special case",
    "when @xmath3 is unimodular this was proved in ( * ? ? ?",
    "* lemma 10.14 ) .",
    "[ virtual - fiber ] a monomial ideal @xmath32 is a virtual initial ideal of @xmath10 if and only if , for every @xmath103 , the polyhedron @xmath171 is either empty or @xmath171 contains a unique lattice point @xmath255 such that @xmath256 is not in @xmath32 .",
    "the map @xmath257 is a bijection between the set of lattice points in @xmath171 and the set of monomials in @xmath241 having degree @xmath258 .",
    "hence the condition in the lemma states that every non - zero graded component of @xmath241 contains exactly one monomial which is not in @xmath32 .    in ( * ?",
    "* proposition 10.8 ) it was shown that the lattice point @xmath255 chosen as in lemma [ virtual - fiber ] need not be a vertex of the polyhedron @xmath171 .",
    "this is not the case for initial ideals of @xmath10 , and the following important lemma states that it is also not the case if @xmath259 .",
    "we first show that every monomial in @xmath265 lies in the monomial ideal @xmath266 . in polyhedral terms ,",
    "if @xmath255 is any lattice point in @xmath267 , then @xmath255 can be written as @xmath268 where @xmath269 and the @xmath270 are non - negative reals summing to @xmath163 .",
    "this means that for the corresponding monomial @xmath174 we have @xmath271 , where @xmath272 , since @xmath273 .",
    "there exists an index @xmath274 such that @xmath275 and this implies that @xmath276 , and thus that @xmath277 divides @xmath278 .",
    "this shows that @xmath279 lies in @xmath280 .    since our virtual initial ideal @xmath32 must have a standard monomial of degree @xmath281",
    ", it can not contain the ideal @xmath282 , and we conclude that one of the monomials @xmath283 is not in @xmath32 , as desired .",
    "we next present an alternative characterization of triangulations of @xmath31 , and hence of virtual chambers of @xmath3 .",
    "a subset @xmath284 of the closed orthant @xmath285 is an _ order ideal _ if @xmath286 and @xmath287 coordinatewise implies @xmath288 .",
    "let @xmath289 be the linear map @xmath290 from @xmath285 onto @xmath291 .",
    "a section of @xmath289 is a map @xmath292 such that the composition @xmath293 is the identity on @xmath294 .",
    "note that every triangulation @xmath295 of @xmath31 defines a section @xmath296 as follows : @xmath297 is the unique vector @xmath298 with @xmath299 and whose support is a cell of @xmath74 .",
    "the image @xmath300 of such a section @xmath301 is an order ideal in @xmath285 .",
    "it is clear that the section @xmath307 associated to a triangulation @xmath74 of @xmath31 satisfies the desired conditions , so we need only show that every section @xmath304 satisfying the hypothesis comes from a triangulation .",
    "we claim that the set of all possible supports of vectors in @xmath305 is a triangulation of @xmath31 .",
    "we first show that the subsets of @xmath31 indexed by these supports are linearly independent .",
    "suppose not , so for some @xmath316 there is a vector @xmath317 such that @xmath299 where @xmath318 is a proper subset of @xmath319 .",
    "there is some @xmath137 for which @xmath320 , and so @xmath321 .",
    "now @xmath322 , so @xmath323 this implies that @xmath324 , a contradiction since @xmath319 properly contains @xmath318 .",
    "this shows that the cones @xmath325 as @xmath248 ranges over @xmath326 are simplicial and that they cover @xmath326 .",
    "we also note that this argument actually shows that for any @xmath327 in the relative interior of @xmath328 we have @xmath329 .",
    "hence the relative interiors of two distinct cones do not intersect .",
    "the order ideal hypothesis guarantees that these cones form a simplicial fan .",
    "this bijection means we can express the map in theorem [ unimodular2 ] as taking a virtual initial ideal @xmath32 to a section @xmath304 such that @xmath330 is an order ideal in @xmath285 .",
    "fix @xmath32 .",
    "for @xmath331 we set @xmath332 where @xmath255 is given by lemma [ vvvertex ] .",
    "since @xmath333 we can extend this to all rational @xmath120 , and hence to all @xmath334 by continuity .",
    "now we are ready to prove theorem [ unimodular2 ] .",
    "recall that a polyhedron @xmath120 is tight if and only if the greatest common divisor of all monomials of the form @xmath175 for @xmath147 is one .",
    "if @xmath120 is not tight , let @xmath335 be the greatest common divisor of all monomials of the corresponding degree .",
    "then if a monomial ideal @xmath336 is generated in tight degrees , @xmath337 implies @xmath338 where @xmath339 for some @xmath147 .",
    "we first present the part of the proof that holds for a general configuration .",
    "[ nontight ] let @xmath174 divide @xmath340 , and let @xmath335 and @xmath341 be the greatest common divisors of all monomials of the same degree as @xmath174 and @xmath340 respectively .",
    "then @xmath342 divides @xmath343 .",
    "suppose this is not the case , so there is some @xmath36 with @xmath344 .",
    "since the greatest common divisor of all monomials of the same degree as @xmath342 is @xmath345 , we know that @xmath346 is tight , and so there is some lattice point @xmath347 such that @xmath348 . because @xmath349 , we also have @xmath350 .",
    "this means @xmath351 is a monomial of the same degree as @xmath352 , and is thus divisible by @xmath341 , so @xmath353 .",
    "but this implies that @xmath354 , a contradiction .",
    "_ proof of theorem [ unimodular2 ] _ : for each virtual chamber of @xmath3 we will construct a virtual initial ideal which maps to it .",
    "the construction will make it clear that this map is injective .",
    "let @xmath304 be the section of @xmath289 corresponding to our virtual chamber , as described in lemma [ section ] .",
    "it is straightforward to check that @xmath355 is a vertex of the polyhedron @xmath120 for every @xmath356 .",
    "we define @xmath32 to be the ideal generated by all monomials @xmath357 such that @xmath120 is tight and @xmath121 is not in the image of @xmath304 .",
    "we claim that @xmath32 is a virtual initial ideal . by construction",
    ", @xmath32 has at most one standard monomial in every tight degree , and thus in every degree .",
    "tight polyhedra are integral by theorem [ tight = tdi ] and lemma [ iftdi ] .",
    "if @xmath120 is tight then @xmath355 is a vertex of @xmath331 and hence @xmath358 .",
    "we claim @xmath359 for all @xmath121 such that @xmath120 is tight . if not , there is some generator @xmath340 of @xmath32 with @xmath360 tight dividing @xmath361 .",
    "but since @xmath305 is an order ideal , we must have @xmath362 , contradicting @xmath363 . therefore @xmath359 .",
    "if @xmath120 is not tight , let @xmath335 be the greatest common divisor of all monomials of degree @xmath364 .",
    "then we claim that @xmath365 , where @xmath366 satisfies @xmath367 for @xmath368 .",
    "otherwise there would be some generator @xmath340 of @xmath32 with @xmath340 dividing @xmath369 .",
    "but since @xmath360 would then be a tight degree , lemma [ nontight ] would imply that @xmath340 must divide @xmath174 , a contradiction .",
    "this concludes the proof that @xmath32 is a virtual initial ideal .",
    "the virtual initial ideal @xmath32 just constructed is clearly mapped back to @xmath304 under the map ( described after lemma [ section ] ) from virtual initial ideals to triangulations .",
    "hence this map is a bijection as desired .",
    "* acknowledgement .",
    "* we thank miguel azaola , ernest croot , jess de loera , tracy hall , marc pfetsch , jrg rambau , francisco santos , and gnter ziegler for permitting us to discuss their work in section  [ polygon ] ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> a configuration of lattice vectors is supernormal if it contains a hilbert basis for every cone spanned by a subset . </S>",
    "<S> we study such configurations from various perspectives , including triangulations , integer programming and grbner bases . </S>",
    "<S> our main result is a bijection between virtual chambers of the configuration and virtual initial ideals of the associated binomial ideal . </S>"
  ]
}
